Configure settings for Polyspace Copilot
Analysis Engine
Polyspace installation folder:

The Polyspace extension autofills this setting with the folder path specified during the installation of Polyspace as You Code. \nIn some cases, you might need to manually specify this path. \nThe installation folder path typically ends with 'Polyspace as You Code\\Rxxxxy' or 'PolyspaceAsYouCode/Rxxxxy', where Rxxxxy is the release number.
Working directory:

Specify a working directory path for Polyspace as You Code. 
Polyspace as You Code stores temporary information in this folder, including the baselines you create or download. 
If no path is specified, the extension uses the subfolder 'polyspace_as_you_code' in your system's temp folder. 
The path name must contain only ASCII characters.
Baseline
Baseline Mode:

A baseline allows you to compare an analysis with a previously computed result. It may allow to show only new results, or to apply review comments and justifications from the integration runs to your results. \nChanging this setting will stop any pending analysis and clear previous analysis results for all the files in the Quality Monitoring list.
Local baseline
Polyspace Access baseline
Create your own copy of results to serve as baseline for the subsequent runs.
Import baseline from Polyspace Access Web. Apply collaborative review comments and hide findings that are justified in the baseline.
Polyspace Access settings
Show Baseline information:

A baseline allows you to apply review comments and justifications from the integration runs to your results. \nTo download baseline, use the [Polyspace: Download Baseline](command:polyspace.downloadBaseline) command from Command Palette. \nChanging this setting will stop any pending analysis and clear previous analysis results for all the files in the Quality Monitoring list.

A baseline allows you to apply review comments and justifications from the integration runs to your results. \nTo download baseline, use the Download Baseline command. \nChanging this setting will stop any pending analysis and clear previous analysis results for all the files in the Quality Monitoring list.
Show local findings only
Show local findings and baseline info
Show new findings only
Do not use baseline.
Import baseline information into current run. This option hides findings that are justified in the baseline.
Import baseline and show only new findings compared to baseline.
Polyspace Access URL:
Provide URL to get results baseline from Polyspace Access server. \nTo refresh baseline, use the [Polyspace: Download Baseline](command:polyspace.downloadBaseline) command from Command Palette.
Provide URL to get results baseline from Polyspace Access server. \nTo refresh baseline, use the Download Baseline command.
Polyspace Access Login:
Specify Polyspace Access username. You will be prompted for the password when you get a results baseline.
Project path:
Provide project path to get results baseline. In Polyspace Access, right-click a project and copy its path.
Language of the discussion
Choice of online model
Token key for access to MW-AI service

Create your Copilot personality by selecting how technical, verbose, and formal you want the responses to be. 

You can use the following examples: 
- **Technical Support** — Code-heavy / Verbose / Formal
- **Advisor** — Balanced / Informative / Neutral
- **Friend** — Balanced / Informative / Friendly
- **Bot** — Code-heavy / Succint / Formal 

Begin a new conversation after changing the setting to see the new persona in action.
Content Presentation
Summary
Balanced
Code-heavy
Copilot gives explanations in plain language with few code snippets. Good for new users.
Copilot balances between code snippets and text in its answers.
Copilot provides code snippets as much as possible alongside highly technical responses.
Wordiness
Verbose
Informative
Succint
Copilot provides longer answers with more details.
Copilot provides moderately detailed responses.
Copilot provides short answers.
Language Tone
Friendly
Neutral
Formal
Copilot will respond in a casual tone.
Copilot will respond in a balanced, professional tone.
Copilot responds formally.
Copilot proposes follow-up questions in the conversation chat.
Copilot attempts to propose a fix in a diff view for each fix line in the Result Details View. \nThis is a preview. Results may not be accurate.
Show findings in included files.
Add to Quality Monitoring list on save
Add file to Quality Monitoring list on save.
Start analysis on save
Start analysis when saving a file in the Quality Monitoring list.
Perform analysis in fast-mode
Decreases the duration of your analysis runtime by deactivating checkers that rely on numerical propagation.
Does not deactivate checkers when creating a local baseline.
Manually
Polyspace Analysis Options
Analysis Setup
Use a script to configure and run analysis (in setting [scriptFile](#polyspace.analysisOptions.script.scriptFile)), \nor specify each setting explicitly (in settings group Manual Setup).
Use a script to configure and run analysis, \nor specify each setting explicitly (in settings group `Manual Setup`).
Manual setup
Script
Specify how Polyspace obtains the build information, which checkers to enable, and additional options in the extension settings.
Specify how Polyspace obtains the build information, which checkers to enable, and additional options in the extension settings.
Specify how Polyspace obtains the build information, which checkers to enable, and additional options in the extension settings.
Specify how Polyspace obtains the build information, which checkers to enable, and additional options in the extension settings.
Script File:

Enter full path to script file. 
Each time you start an analysis, Polyspace runs the script and shows the analysis results that the script returns. The extension always passes 3 arguments to the script, in this order: The path of the file to analyze; The results folder path; The installation folder path. 
The extension also passes the path of an options file prefixed with `-options-file` and the path of a checkers activation XML or pschk file prefixed with `-checkers-activation-file` when you specify those paths in the settings [otherAnalysisOptionsFile](#polyspace.analysisOptions.otherAnalysisOptionsFile) and [checkersFile](#polyspace.analysisOptions.checkersFile) respectively. 
The extension also passes the path to a local baseline or an Access Web downloaded baseline prefixed with '-baseline-folder'. 
To pass additional parameters to the script, enter them in setting [scriptFileArguments](#polyspace.analysisOptions.script.scriptFileArguments). 
For an example, use the [Polyspace: Open Polyspace Documentation](command:polyspace.openDocumentation) command from the Command Palette and see the topic 'Configure Polyspace as You Code Extension in Visual Studio Code'.

Enter full path to script file. 
Each time you start an analysis, Polyspace runs the script and shows the analysis results that the script returns. The plugin always passes 3 arguments to the script, in this order: The path of the file to analyze; The results folder path; The installation folder path. 
The plugin also passes the path of an options file prefixed with '-options-file' and the path of a checkers activation XML or pschk file prefixed with '-checkers-activation-file' when you specify those paths in the settings 'Other Analysis Options File' and 'Checkers File' respectively. 
The plugin also passes the path to a local baseline or an Access Web downloaded baseline prefixed with '-baseline-folder'. 
To pass additional parameters to the script, enter them in setting 'Script File Arguments'. 
For an example, open the Polyspace documentation and see the topic 'Configure Polyspace as You Code Extension in Eclipse'.

Enter full path to script file. 
Each time you start an analysis, Polyspace runs the script and shows the analysis results that the script returns. The plugin always passes 3 arguments to the script, in this order: The path of the file to analyze; The results folder path; The installation folder path. 
The plugin also passes the path of an options file prefixed with '-options-file' and the path of a checkers activation XML or pschk file prefixed with '-checkers-activation-file' when you specify those paths in the settings 'Other Analysis Options File' and 'Checkers File' respectively. 
The plugin also passes the path to a local baseline or an Access Web downloaded baseline prefixed with '-baseline-folder'. 
To pass additional parameters to the script, enter them in setting 'Script File Arguments'. 
For an example, open the Polyspace documentation and see the topic 'Configure Polyspace as You Code Extension in Visual Studio'.
Script File Arguments:
Enter arguments to pass to the script.
Build:

Select how Polyspace generates build options. \nThe available settings are [buildCommand](#polyspace.analysisOptions.manualSetup.buildSetting.buildCommand), [buildTask](#polyspace.analysisOptions.manualSetup.buildSetting.buildTask), [jsonCompilationDatabaseFile](#polyspace.analysisOptions.manualSetup.buildSetting.jsonCompilationDatabaseFile) and [polyspaceBuildOptionsFile](#polyspace.analysisOptions.manualSetup.buildSetting.polyspaceBuildOptionsFile). If you select 'buildCommand' or 'buildTask', run the command: Generate Build Options to generate build options. Regenerate the build options each time you make changes to your project.

Select how Polyspace generates build options. \nIf you select "Get from Build Command", run the command Generate Build Options in the Polyspace Configuration View to generate build options. Regenerate the build options each time you make changes to your project.
Build options file not required
Get from build command
Get from build task
Get from Eclipse C/C++ Project
Get from Visual Studio C++ Project
Get from JSON Compilation Database file
JSON Compilation Database (*.json)
Get from Polyspace build options file
Start without any build options.

Paste your build command. Use a build command that does a **full** build of all files in folder or workspace. \nTo generate the build options, run Generate Build Options in the Polyspace Configuration View. Regenerate the build options each time you make changes to your project.

Provide build task name (as appears when you select Terminal > Run Task) in `buildTask` setting. Use a build task that does a **full** build of all files in folder or workspace. \nTo generate the build options, run Generate Build Options in the Polyspace Configuration View. Regenerate the build options each time you make changes to your project.
Provide full path to JSON file (e.g. `compile_command.json`) in `jsonCompilationDatabaseFile` setting.
Provide full path to analysis options file in `polyspaceBuildOptionsFile` setting. The options file is a text file with one option per line.
Start without any build options.

Paste your build command. Use a build command that does a full build of all files in folder or workspace. \nTo generate the build options, run Generate Build Options in the Polyspace Configuration View. Regenerate the build options each time you make changes to your project.
Polyspace extension will extract build information in your C/C++ Project(s) to generate a Compilation Database.
Provide full path to JSON file (e.g. compile_command.json) in "JSON Compilation Database File" setting.
Provide full path to analysis options file in "Polyspace Build Options File" setting. The options file is a text file with one option per line.
Build Command:
Provide a build command that does a full build of all files in folder or workspace. \nRequires [build](#polyspace.analysisOptions.manualSetup.build) setting set to `Get from build command`.
Provide a build command that does a full build of all files in folder or workspace.
Build Task:

Provide build task name. Use a build task that does a full build of all files in folder or workspace. \nRequires [build](#polyspace.analysisOptions.manualSetup.build) setting set to `Get from build task`.
Provide build task name. Use a build task that does a full build of all files in folder or workspace.
Eclipse Build mode:
Choose how to get JSON Compilation Database.
Get from CCDB setting field
External file
JSON Compilation Database file:
Provide full path to JSON file (e.g. `compile_command.json`). \nRequires [build](#polyspace.analysisOptions.manualSetup.build) setting set to `Get from JSON Compilation Database file`.
Provide full path to JSON file (e.g. compile_command.json).
Polyspace Build Options File:
Provide full path to analysis options text file, with one option per line. \nRequires [build](#polyspace.analysisOptions.manualSetup.build) setting set to `Get from Polyspace build options file`.
Provide full path to analysis options text file, with one option per line.
Checkers File:

Provide full path to XML or pschk file with checkers selection. Use the [Polyspace: Configure Checkers](command:polyspace.configureCheckers) command from Command Palette to create this file. \nFor information on importing from a Polyspace project (.psprj), use the [Polyspace: Open Documentation](command:polyspace.openDocumentation) command from Command Palette and then search for "Import Checkers Configuration from Desktop Project".

Provide full path to XML or pschk file with checkers selection. Use the Polyspace: Configure Checkers command to create this file. \nFor information on importing from a Polyspace project (.psprj), search for "Import Checkers Configuration from Desktop Project" in the Polyspace documentation.
Checkers File (*.xml; *.pschk)
All files (*.*)
Other Analysis Options File:
Provide full path to analysis options text file, with one option per line. \nUse this file only for options unrelated to build or checkers selection.
Polyspace justification
Justification catalog:

Provide full path of justifications catalog file. The extension proposes these justifications to autocomplete code annotations that you type in the editor.\n Catalog must use JSON format and UTF-8 encoding.
Polyspace justification catalog (*.json)
Other
Debug Mode:
Debug Mode
Use this setting to help debug issues with Polyspace as You Code.
Disabled
Enabled
Show only errors, warnings, and info messages in Output panel.
Show debugging information in Output Panel.
Help Improve Polyspace As You Code
Help us improve Polyspace as You Code by sharing user experience information with MathWorks.
Port

Port that the Polyspace as You Code extension uses to establish an internal connection with the Polyspace analysis engine when you start the extension. \nBy default, port 0 is specified and the extension attempts to use a random free port on your system. You might need to re-run Polyspace: Generate Build Options when you restart Visual Studio Code. \nIf you run multiple instances of Polyspace as You Code, specify a different port number for each instance. You might need to reload Visual Studio Code after changing this setting.

Port that the Polyspace as You Code extension uses to establish an internal connection with the Polyspace analysis engine when you start the extension. \nBy default, port 0 is specified and the extension attempts to use a random free port on your system. You might need to re-run Polyspace: Generate Build Options when you restart Eclipse. \nIf you run multiple instances of Polyspace as You Code, specify a different port number for each instance. You might need to reload Eclipse after changing this setting.

Port that the Polyspace as You Code extension uses to establish an internal connection with the Polyspace analysis engine when you start the extension. \nBy default, port 0 is specified and the extension attempts to use a random free port on your system. You might need to re-run Polyspace: Generate Build Options when you restart Visual Studio. \nIf you run multiple instances of Polyspace as You Code, specify a different port number for each instance. You might need to reload Visual Studio after changing this setting.
Headers Extensions:

Specify extensions of header files. 
Polyspace treats files with the specified extensions as header files instead of source files. If you make edits to these headers files, they are not added to the Quality Monitoring list when you configure Polyspace to add files to that list automatically (on save). 
Polyspace analyzes a header file when one of these is true, even if you do not specify that header file extension in this setting:
* You analyze a source file that includes the header file. Header file findings appear in the Header view.
* You manually start a Polyspace analysis of the header file.
Browse…

Warning: Generated DDUX settings file {0} is invalid. Polyspace cannot detect your opt-in or opt-out selection for sharing user experience information with MathWorks.

Error: Analysis configured to use a script but no Polyspace results available after script execution returned a successful exit status. Check the content of your script. One possible reason for this error is that the script is returning an incorrect exit status.
Error: buildTask setting is empty, whereas the build mode has been set to 'Get from Build Task'.
Build task "{0}" does not exist or is not considered valid by Visual Studio Code.
The Polyspace as You Code extension does not support build task "{0}" because it is not in the build group ("group": "build"). The extension can execute only task that belong to the build group.

The Polyspace as You Code extension does not support build task "{0}" because it has no command property. Specify or create a task of type shell ("type": "shell") and provide an appropriate shell command for the command property.
The Polyspace as You Code extension does not support build task "{0}" because it uses predefined variables: {1}. As a workaround, create a task that does not use predefined variables.
Build task "{0}" contains predefined variables that are not supported by the Polyspace extension: {1}.

The Polyspace as You Code extension does not support build task "{0}" with execution property ProcessExecution. As a workaround, create a task of type shell ("type": "shell") with the appropriate shell command.

The Polyspace as You Code extension does not support build task "{0}" with execution property CustomExecution. As a workaround, create a task of type shell ("type": "shell") with the appropriate shell command.

The Polyspace as You Code extension does not support the IAR task "iar: Build Project". As a workaround, create a task of type shell ("type": "shell") with the appropriate shell command to build a project. For instance: "command": "$builder/common/bin/iarbuild.exe $project -make $config" where $builder, $project, and $config are the values of the "builder", "project", and "config" keys in the "iar: Build Project" task.
Error: Polyspace cannot find any C/C++ project. No build information to extract.

Copilot Chat sometimes produces output that seems accurate but is not. Validate generated output before use. Share feedback on the output to help improve the responses.

entry.note: hole 0: number of this conversation, hole 1: total number of conversations

message.entry: Conversation {0}/{1}
General Topics

Hello! Copilot is here to answer your questions, help finding bugs and coding rules violations with Polyspace, understand, fix and justify issues. Here, Copilot has access to the Polyspace documentation but not to your code.
Explain Finding

Hello! Copilot received some information from Polyspace about this finding (characteristics of the finding and some lines of code). \nThis conversation aims at discussing this finding. To discuss other topics, you should better create a new conversation.
Fix Finding

Hello! Copilot received some information from Polyspace about this finding (characteristics of the finding and some lines of code). \nThis conversation aims at discussing how to fix this finding. To discuss other topics, you should better create a new conversation.
Explain Fix

Hello! Copilot received some information from Polyspace about this finding and the fix previously proposed in a diff view (characteristics of the finding, the code around and the proposed fix). \nThis conversation aims at discussing the proposed fix for this finding. To discuss other topics, you should better create a new conversation.

entry.note: hole 0: finding name, hole 1: line, hole 2: file

message.entry: To improve Polyspace as You Code, the extension sends user experience information to MathWorks. [Learn more](https://www.mathworks.com/support/faq/user_experience_information_faq.html). If you do not want to send user experience information, update your settings.

entry.note: do not change wording - message reviewed by DDUX team

message.entry: To improve Polyspace as You Code, the extension sends user experience information to MathWorks.\nLearn more at https://www.mathworks.com/support/faq/user_experience_information_faq.html.\nIf you do not want to send user experience information, update your settings.
You have selected to share Polyspace as You Code user experience information with MathWorks. To stop sharing usage data, use the setting 'polyspace.otherSettings.helpImprovePolyspaceAsYouCode'.

You have selected to share Polyspace as You Code user experience information with MathWorks. To stop sharing usage data, use the setting "Help Improve Polyspace As You Code" in the Polyspace Preferences.

You have selected to NOT share Polyspace as You Code user experience information with MathWorks. To share user experience information and help improve Polyspace as You Code, use the setting 'polyspace.otherSettings.helpImprovePolyspaceAsYouCode'.

You have selected to NOT share Polyspace as You Code user experience information with MathWorks. To share user experience information and help improve Polyspace as You Code, use the setting "Help Improve Polyspace As You Code" in the Polyspace Preferences.

You have selected during the installation process to share Polyspace as You Code user experience information with MathWorks. To stop sharing usage data, use the setting 'polyspace.otherSettings.helpImprovePolyspaceAsYouCode'.

You have selected during the installation process to share Polyspace as You Code user experience information with MathWorks. To stop sharing usage data, use the setting "Help Improve Polyspace As You Code" in the Polyspace Preferences.

You have selected during the installation process to NOT share Polyspace as You Code user experience information with MathWorks. To share user experience information and help improve Polyspace as You Code, use the setting 'polyspace.otherSettings.helpImprovePolyspaceAsYouCode'.

You have selected during the installation process to NOT share Polyspace as You Code user experience information with MathWorks. To share user experience information and help improve Polyspace as You Code, use the setting "Help Improve Polyspace As You Code" in the Polyspace Preferences.

To improve Polyspace as You Code, the extension sends user experience information to MathWorks. If you do not want to send user experience information, change the setting 'polyspace.otherSettings.helpImprovePolyspaceAsYouCode'.

To improve Polyspace as You Code, the extension sends user experience information to MathWorks. If you do not want to send user experience information, change the setting "Help Improve Polyspace As You Code" in the Polyspace Preferences.
No changes in Source Control.
No C/C++ files in these changes.

Acronym for the standard for a Polyspace justification

Acronym for the rule for a Polyspace justification

Severity to apply to the Polyspace finding

Invalid format for justifications catalog "{0}".
Justifications catalog does not exist: {0}.
Polyspace as You Code - 1 - Configure
How to set up Polyspace as You Code.
Polyspace as You Code - 2 - Review Results
How to review results of Polyspace as You Code.
Polyspace as You Code - 3 - Baseline
How to work with baselines in Polyspace as You Code.
Configure the Build

You can configure the build of your files either manually or automatically for a simple project or for experimentation.\nYou may need to launch the build of the project before launching the analysis of a file.\n[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.analysisOptions.manual%22%5D)
Automatically monitor the quality of all modified files

Allow Polyspace to add files to the Quality Monitoring list when you save them.\n[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.analysisOptions.addToQualityMonitoringOnSave%22%5D)
Alternatively, manually choose files for Polyspace to monitor quality

Right-click files in the VSCode Explorer to add them to the Quality Monitoring list.\n[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.analysisOptions.addToQualityMonitoringOnSave%22%5D)
Set Polyspace to analyze files on save
Polyspace launches an analysis when you save a file.\n[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.analysisOptions.analysisOfFilesOnSave%22%5D)
Alternatively, manually launch Polyspace analysis

You can launch the analysis of individual files or all files on the Quality Monitoring list.\nMulti-selection in the view is possible.\n[See the Quality Monitoring View](command:polyspaceView.analyses.focus)
Configure checkers
Select the defects and standards Polyspace analyzes code for such as MISRA, AUTOSAR-C++14...\n[Polyspace: Configure Checkers](command:polyspace.configureCheckers)
Analyze headers as source files

You can analyze a header file as if it were a source file.
 Provide the build information in build settings.
 The headers must be compilable.
 Headers must be added manually to the Quality Monitoring list.
 Define the extensions of your headers with the setting:
[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.otherSettings.headersExtensions%22%5D)
Configure for a regular use in your environment
To fit your build environment, you can configure the build of your files with a script.\n[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.analysisOptions.script%22%5D)
Script setting.
Understand a Polyspace finding

View Polyspace as You Code findings in the Problems tab of VSCode
 Use the VSCode filter to filter Polyspace as You Code findings.
 Click on a result in the Problems tab to view the file and line of code.
[Show the Problems View](command:workbench.actions.view.problems)
Fix findings

Polyspace as You Code locates errors in your development environment as soon as they are inserted.\n Fix findings, run analysis, and check that your file is displayed in green in the Quality Monitoring list.
Automatically fix findings
Polyspace as You Code might propose fixes.\n Apply automatic fixes to one finding or all findings of the same kind. Click the light bulb icon to view suggested fixes.
Justify findings
You can add a comment in the code to justify a finding. Polyspace ignores this finding on subsequent analyses.
View findings in headers

Access findings in headers by clicking on the file in the Quality Monitoring list.
 The Problems tab shows the findings in both the analyzed source file and headers.
 The findings displayed are contextual to the usage of the header in this source file.
[Show the Headers View](command:polyspaceView.headers.focus)
Provide a catalog of allowed justifications

Provide a catalog of justifications for consistency and accuracy when justifying findings.\n Catalog justifications are suggested options when justifying individual findings.\n[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.justification.catalog%22%5D)
Review copy-paste findings

To view and fix potential clone and copy-paste findings side-by-side, click the peek view button ($(diff)) in the Result Details pane.\n[Show the Result Details View](command:polyspaceView.resultDetail.focus)
Work with a local baseline
Create a local baseline for your file and have subsequent analyses only show findings in the code you changed.\n[See the Baseline View](command:polyspaceView.baselines.focus)
Create or update local baselines for all your files

Create or refresh local baselines for each of your files in the Quality Monitoring List by using the icon in the Baseline view or by selecting multiple files and using the right-click context menu in the Explorer view.
Configure Polyspace Access settings

Set your Polyspace Access baseline information using your Polyspace Access URL, login, and project information.\n[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.baseline%22%5D)
Download a Polyspace Access baseline for your project
Download a Polyspace Access baseline to compare local findings with baseline information and get review information.\n[Show the Baseline View](command:polyspaceView.baselines.focus)
Show only new results compared to Access baseline

You can have Polyspace as You Code compare your code with a Polyspace Access baseline and display only the findings that are new compared to the integration run.\n[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.baseline%22%5D)
Take advantage of integration review

Keep your review information up to date by downloading the latest review information from Polyspace Access.\n[Show setting](command:toSide:workbench.action.openSettings?%5B%22polyspace.baseline%22%5D)
